text: - I want to start

We are, believe it or not, one
month to 100 days, which some

consider an artificial
deadline, but Washington
always tries to keep score.

How much is this
constant focus--

Russia investigations, push
back, new developments,

anger at the White
House that we're
even covering this story--

how much is it affecting
this president's
ability to get stuff done?
MAGGIE HABERMAN: Quite a bit.
I mean, look.

The issue-- and to your point,
he's good at misdirection,
and we hear about that a lot.

There's been a big theory
in Washington for a while

now that every time
the president tweets,

it's some kind of a distraction
from something else.

That's like saying that you're
burning your hand to distract
from your burning ear.

This is not good every
time he calls attention
back to this, frankly.
And when he characterizes it--

Russia-- just broadly Russia--
as fake news or a scam,

it sounds like he's talking
about the entire story.

Remember, the only thing that we
do know is there was a hacking.

And that 17 different divisions
of the intelligence community

say that this was done
with a high degree--
relatively high in one case--
degree of confidence by Russia.

And that this was done to
help elevate his campaign.

So he sounds like
he is dismissing
all of that when he does this.
- Right.

MAGGIE HABERMAN: The White
House has been unable to get
out of its own way on this.

And part of that,
as you know, is

that this president, when he
feels like he is under attack,
he attacks back.

But now he's punching
at ghosts and hitting
himself in the face.
- Punching at ghosts.

And part of the
problem-- look, you know,
I try to come at the sit--
OK.
Listen to them.
Listen to what they say.
Nothing nefarious happened.
These were just meetings.

But, however, we
asked for months.

How many meetings did your
people have in the campaign
with Russian officials?
The president himself said none.

Then we find out
there were some.

We find out Jared Kushner
met with the ambassador.

Told us that only after it was
made public in your newspaper,
I believe.

We found out Jared Kushner later
met with a big Russian banker

close to Putin, found
out that he disclosed

that only after he knew
the Senate Intelligence
Committee knew about it.

Now, we find out Michael
Flynn, who had to resign,

didn't put on his
financial disclosure form

speaking fees and other money
he took from Russian interests.

When he took the job, he
knew this was a big story.

Now again, that doesn't mean
anything nefarious happened.
But it does make you wonder.

JACKIE KUCINICH: Well
yeah, and that's the thing.

I mean, in terms of
not being able to get
out of their own way.

If it was just the tweets,
maybe they could move past it.
It's not.

It's the more they--
it's like quicksand.

The more they thrash, the
deeper they go into this.

And the more that we
find out information,

like the most recent Michael
Flynn not claiming money

he made from RT and money from
speeches, on his disclosure

forms, as you said,
it just it raises
more questions than it answers.

And that is a trend
throughout this investigation

and throughout this
issue with Russia.
Something else comes up.

And it doesn't
answer any questions.

ABBY PHILLIP: And
Trump is also creating
a lot of problems for himself.

Remember this whole wiretapping
thing was created just
because he wanted to respond.

He opened up a whole
new avenue of problems

for his administration
which, this week,

we learned have stretched into
three White House aides giving

information,
essentially, to the House

Intelligence Committee
chairman, putting
his credibility into question.

Really opening a
Pandora's box of problems,

just because the
president wanted to--

maybe it was misdirection,
or maybe it was just
to fire back at his critics.

But when you create new
problems for yourself,
that's hurting yourself.

- And he-- to that point,
he is now seizing--

one of his tweets yesterday--
and if you look at Fox News,

if you look at
Breitbart, you look
around at conservative media--

he is now seizing on a Fox News
report that anonymously quotes

a high ranking official
who says someone very

senior in the Obama
administration, a known person

in the intelligence community,
unmasked, spread these reports.

Trump transition officials
picked up on some surveillance
that's perfectly legal.

Unmasking them-- meaning
disclosing their names

or at least making clear
who they are-- that
would be very, very unusual.
They say this happened.

Well, no one else has
been able to confirm
that report, number one.

There's a lot of good
reporters working this story.

But number two, I
would make this point.

If that's the case, if there
was a serious, irresponsible,

reckless effort in the
Obama administration

to spread this stuff around,
the president has the power
to declassify these documents.

He could make this
go away like that.

Instead, we get this
innuendo, and back and forth.
He could end this in a minute.

And if he wanted
to protect himself,

he could bring in
establishment people

from prior administrations
who have security clearances,
and say look what we found.

Please help us make the
case that we're not nuts.

Instead, this is all
spread through this--
so that's why I'm skeptical.
